 ARTIST: A-Ha

/Hartwig_Stefan/Ultimate_Intro_Studio.sid
(#3)
COMMENT: Also used in the games Opium, (c) 19?? Heaven Artworks, and
         "Iceblaster", (c) 1994 Dome Developments.
(#4)
  TITLE: Living on Video [from Living on Video] (0:11)
 ARTIST: Trans-X
(#6)
COMMENT: Later used as Side Border Music, (c) 1990 Digital Excess.
         This tune later was also used as loader tune for the System 3 game
         Vendetta, that - just like Myth and Turrican - was timex protected and
         mastered by Markus Wiederstein. In need for a loader tune Wiederstein
         chose tunes the composer gave to Digital Marketing. That's why
         Hartwig's tunes ended up in the games.
(#7)
COMMENT: Later used as the loading theme to the disk version of "Myth", (c)
         1989 System 3.

/Hartwig_Stefan/X-ample_Intro_Architect.sid
(#1)
COMMENT: Later used as the disk loading theme to "Turrican", (c) 1990 Rainbow
         Arts.
(#6)
COMMENT: Later used as the intro theme to the disk version of "Turrican 2 - The
         Final Fight", (c) 1991 Rainbow Arts.

### /Hubbard_Rob #############################################################

/Hubbard_Rob/
COMMENT: All of these tunes have been confirmed by Hubbard to be his. People
         have often stolen Hubbard's routine causing some tunes to be falsely
         credited to him.
         Hubbard's own comments are denoted by (RH).

/Hubbard_Rob/ACE_II.sid
COMMENT: "This was supposed to be the usual Top Gun type Danger Zone music. It
         turned out much better than I expected as certain musical styles can
         be difficult to do on the C64." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Action_Biker.sid
COMMENT: "Action B was a very early game and very conservative in its approach
         - it was my idea of giving them what I thought they wanted, a simple
         cute tune....." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Auf_Wiedersehen_Monty.sid
COMMENT: Tune #1 is a joint venture between Rob Hubbard and Ben Daglish. The
         other sub-tunes were done by Rob Hubbard.
         "I just think that Gremlin thought that the original Monty On The Run
         was very popular and they just didn't want to totally move away from
         what I did on the original, so they asked me to spend 2 days working
         with Ben at their office and that's what happened." (RH)
(#2)
  TITLE: God Save the King/Queen (The National Anthem of the U.K.)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: This anthem is traditional and possibly one of the most known national
         anthems in the world. Each verse was written at a different time,
         ranging from the 1740s to the present day.
(#3)
  TITLE: La Marseillaise (French National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle
(#4)
  TITLE: Deutschlandlied (German National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Franz Joseph Haydn (music), A. H. Hoffmann von Fallersleben (lyrics)
(#5)
  TITLE: O Tannenbaum
 ARTIST: Traditional, A. Zarnack & Ernst Anschütz (lyrics)
COMMENT: German folk song.
(#6)
  TITLE: Symphony No. 40, First Movement
 ARTIST: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
(#9)
  TITLE: Zorba, the Greek
 ARTIST: Mikis Theodorakis
(#10)
  TITLE: 'O sole mio
 ARTIST: Eduardo di Capua (music), Giovanni Capurro (lyrics)
COMMENT: During the 80s, Wall's Ice Cream used this music for their "Cornetto"
         commercials, "Just one cornetto, give it to me!"  It may explain why
         it is used as an Italian jingle in this game!
(#11)
  TITLE: Viva España
 ARTIST: Leo Caerts (music), Leo Rozenstraten & Leif Nilsson (lyrics)
(#12)
  TITLE: Tulpen uit Amsterdam
 ARTIST: Herman Emmink
(#13)
  TITLE: Swedish Chef Theme [from the TV series Muppet Show]
 ARTIST: <?>
COMMENT: Quite likely inspired by the Swedish Chef Theme, although Rob Hubbard
         doesn't remember ever having heard the original.

/Hubbard_Rob/BMX_Kidz.sid
COMMENT: The sampled voice saying "Go!" is actually Hubbard himself!
(#1)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
(#2)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
(#3)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
(#4)
 AUTHOR: Jori Olkkonen (Yip)
  TITLE: Fifth Dream About Happiness
 ARTIST: Yip
COMMENT: Yip did this hi-score music, which is the 'reprise' version of "5th
         Dream About Happiness" found in /Yip/Scroll_Machine.sid #1.

/Hubbard_Rob/BMX_Kidz_PSID.sid
COMMENT: The sampled voice saying "Go!" is actually Hubbard himself!
(#1)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
(#2)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
(#3)
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
(#4)
 AUTHOR: Jori Olkkonen (Yip)
  TITLE: Fifth Dream About Happiness
 ARTIST: Yip
COMMENT: Yip did this hi-score music, which is the 'reprise' version of "5th
         Dream About Happiness" found in /Yip/Scroll_Machine.sid #1.

/Hubbard_Rob/Bangkok_Knights.sid
  TITLE: Eye of the Tiger [from the movie Rocky III] (5:43-6:00)
 ARTIST: Survivor

/Hubbard_Rob/Chain_Reaction.sid
  TITLE: Zoolook (remix) [from Zoolook]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre

/Hubbard_Rob/Chicken_Song.sid
COMMENT: "The Chicken Song" was from the British TV show "Spitting Image", and
         featured ridiculous lyrics such as "Hold a chicken in the air, stick a
         deckchair up your nose". (Please note that STIL does NOT recommend you
         do this!). The song was credited to Spitting Image.
  TITLE: The Chicken Song (0:00)
 ARTIST: Rob Grant, Doug Naylor & Philip Pope, performed by Spitting Image
  TITLE: Anyone Can Fall In Love [from TV series Eastenders] (1:24)
 ARTIST: Anita Dobson featuring the Simon May Orchestra
  TITLE: The Chicken Song (1:55)
 ARTIST: Rob Grant, Doug Naylor & Philip Pope, performed by Spitting Image
  TITLE: The Power of Love (2:39)
 ARTIST: Jennifer Rush
COMMENT: The notes are out of tune.
  TITLE: The Chicken Song (3:17)
 ARTIST: Rob Grant, Doug Naylor & Philip Pope, performed by Spitting Image
  TITLE: Monty on the Run, Tune #1 (4:28)
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

/Hubbard_Rob/Chop_n_Drop.sid
COMMENT: Chop n'Drop was the US version of IK+.
(#1)
   NAME: Loading music
 AUTHOR: <?>
(#2)
   NAME: Ingame music
 AUTHOR: Rob Hubbard
COMMENT: Almost the same as /Hubbard_Rob/IK_plus.sid.

/Hubbard_Rob/Commando.sid
COMMENT: "There is an interesting story behind Commando. I went down to their
         office and started working on it late at night, and worked on it
         through the night. I took one listen to the original arcade version
         and started working on the c64 version. I think they wanted some
         resemblance to the arcade version, but I just did what I wanted to do.
         By the time everyone arrived at 8.00am in the morning, I had loaded
         the main tune on every C64 in the building! I got my cheque and was on
         a train home by 10.00 am..." (RH)
(#1)
  TITLE: BGM1 [from the arcade game Commando]
 ARTIST: Tamayo Kawamoto
(#3)
  TITLE: <?> [from the arcade game Commando]
 ARTIST: Tamayo Kawamoto

/Hubbard_Rob/Confuzion.sid
  TITLE: Confuzion
 ARTIST: Private Property
COMMENT: Included as "Confuzion - The Music" on the B-side of the game tape.

/Hubbard_Rob/Cracker_Mix.sid
COMMENT: Slower version of /Hubbard_Rob/Human_Race.sid, Tune #5.

/Hubbard_Rob/Deep_Strike.sid
  TITLE: March [from the movie "1941"]
 ARTIST: John Williams

/Hubbard_Rob/Delta.sid
COMMENT: "[...] The Delta music loader and ingame music was Gary Liddon's idea.
         [...] He was the producer at Thalamus at the time. He told Rob Hubbard
         to make the ingame music like the 2nd track from Dark Side of the Moon
         by Pink Floyd." (Info from Matt Furniss.)
         "The small jingles are all small clips from Sanxion and Romeo/Juliet
         music. They were all supposed to be for short stingers such as end of
         level, extra life etc..."
         "Delta was based on this minimalist composition technique inspired by
         Glass and a bit of Pink Floyd. It was quite hard to do and required
         some custom code to the driver to do it. The music was tedious to
         debug. The other Delta stuff was more conventional - I quite liked the
         other tunes. Delta was spread over a 2 week period....." (RH)
         According to Hubbard, Kentilla and Delta were the most complicated one
         to compose, they took the longest time to do and they both drove him
         insane.

  TITLE: On the Run [from the Dark Side of the Moon] (0:00)
 ARTIST: Pink Floyd
COMMENT: Inspired by the above tune.

 ARTIST: Philip Glass
COMMENT: Inspired by the above tune.

/Hubbard_Rob/Delta_Mix-E-Load_loader.sid
COMMENT: Delta's intro allowed the user to select the instruments for each
         voice while the game loaded. This rip here is basically a mix of many
         of the instrument combinations selectable in the intro.

/Hubbard_Rob/Dragons_Lair_Part_II.sid
COMMENT: The full title of this game is "Dragon's Lair Part II: Escape From
         Singe's Castle". Several of the songs are covers of the original
         "Dragon's Lair" tunes, see /GAMES/A-F/Dragons_Lair.sid.
         "All the tunes for Dragons Lair 2 were written in 1 afternoon, not the
         whole lot but the basis for them. I sat at the keyboard and just
         recorded myself playing for 3 hours !!" (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Harvey_Smith_Show_Jumper.sid
  TITLE: A Musical Joke
 ARTIST: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
COMMENT: This music was going to be used in the game.  However, Software
         Projects were worried about licencing issues, due to the fact that Rob
         covered the BBC TV Show Jumping theme music (in itself, a cover)
         and so the music was never used.  The music used can be found in
         /GAMES/G-L/Harvey_Smith_Show_Jumper.sid.

/Hubbard_Rob/Hollywood_or_Bust.sid
(#2)
  TITLE: Twelfth Street Rag
 ARTIST: Euday L. Bowman
(#3)
  TITLE: Dill Pickles Rag
 ARTIST: Charles L. Johnson

/Hubbard_Rob/Human_Race.sid
COMMENT: "Human Race was a very interesting project. The tunes tried to capture
         some of the feel of the game, evolution etc... One of the tunes was
         also used for an ST game (GoldRunner I think). I only used 2 SID
         voices for all these tunes because I used the other for SFX...... Most
         of the tunes were sketched out on a small keyboard and manuscript
         paper. I used paper to keep track of the basic ideas and arrangement,
         and I still have all the original manuscripts. A lot of the
         manuscripts are not readable because I used to work very fast and
         never updated many of the changes I made. I used to use a machine code
         monitor to edit music data and sound patch data on the file while the
         tune was playing. This allowed me to really fine tune the SID
         parameters for the music." (RH)
(#4)
COMMENT: Also used in "GoldRunner" on the Atari ST.

/Hubbard_Rob/I-Ball_PSID.sid
COMMENT: "The people doing I-Ball specifically asked for Cabaret Voltaire, so I
         bought the album and tried to give them something that they would
         like. Looking back I don't think the tune really worked very well, and
         some of what I was trying to do was pushing the driver too much. Also,
         I have to admit that I didn't like the album very much." (RH)
(#1)
  TITLE: Whip Blow [from The Covenant The Sword And The Arm Of The Lord] (0:00)
 ARTIST: Cabaret Voltaire
  TITLE: I Want You [from The Covenant The Sword...] (3:10)
 ARTIST: Cabaret Voltaire

/Hubbard_Rob/IK_plus.sid
COMMENT: "I can remember IK very well, but not IK+ so that must tell me
         something." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/International_Karate.sid
  TITLE: Forbidden Colours [from the movie Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence] (0:42-1:16)
 ARTIST: Ryuichi Sakamoto & David Sylvian
  TITLE: Forbidden Colours [from the movie Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence] (2:57-4:04)
 ARTIST: Ryuichi Sakamoto & David Sylvian
  TITLE: Forbidden Colours [from the movie Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence] (9:12-10:26)
 ARTIST: Ryuichi Sakamoto & David Sylvian
COMMENT: "[...] I started exploring pentatonic things in B flat minor over
         different bass notes, B flat, D flat, G flat and A flat. The middle
         section went into F (I think) at double tempo to liven things up. I
         was pleased with the tune......" (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Kentilla.sid
COMMENT: "The whole thing was originally intended to be 'interactive music',
         responding to the different scenes in the game. I originally wrote it
         to work in this fashion, but as per usual in the software business,
         time ran out and they couldn't wait the extra three weeks to finish
         off the music and implement it the way I wanted. So I hacked and
         linked all the different bits together into one long piece." (RH)
         According to Hubbard, Kentilla and Delta were the most complicated one
         to compose, they took the longest time to do and they both drove him
         insane.

/Hubbard_Rob/Kings_of_Beach_intro.sid
COMMENT: James Brown, the Godfather of Soul, is the voice you hear in the
         samples. They don't sound quite like him since the tune is played at
         PAL speed instead of its intended NTSC speed.

/Hubbard_Rob/Kings_of_Beach_intro_PSID.sid
COMMENT: James Brown, the Godfather of Soul, is the voice you hear in the
         samples. They don't sound quite like him since the tune is played at
         PAL speed instead of its intended NTSC speed.

/Hubbard_Rob/Kings_of_the_Beach_ingame.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Waltzing Matilda
 ARTIST: Marie Cowan (music), A.B. Paterson (lyrics)
(#2)
  TITLE: Aloha `Oe
 ARTIST: Queen Lili`uokalani

/Hubbard_Rob/Last_V8.sid
COMMENT: "Last V8 was a simple futuristic game and so I was off into Jarre
         land.... I purposely wrote the 2 melody lines to work off one voice to
         make it sound like more than 1 voice." (RH)
         The Last V8 was the first game released by Mastertronic's new label
         MAD (Mastertronic's Added Dimension). Due to the fact they wanted the
         launch to coincide with the release of the Last V8, the game was rush
         released and therefore unfortunately had a bug, where the
         main theme music (subtune #1) falls out of synch at around the one
         minute mark.  Upon closer investigation, this is due to a mere seven
         bytes of the music player code being incorrect.  This SID has those
         bytes corrected.

/Hubbard_Rob/Last_V8_C128_version.sid
COMMENT: "Last V8 was a simple futuristic game and so I was off into Jarre
         land.... I purposely wrote the 2 melody lines to work off one voice to
         make it sound like more than 1 voice." (RH)
         The Commodore 128 disk-only version had different speech samples from
         the Commodore 64 version.  However it still also exhibited the same
         bug with subtune #1 (see /Hubbard_Rob/Last_V8.sid) which has been
         corrected here too.

/Hubbard_Rob/Last_V8_PSID.sid
COMMENT: "Last V8 was a simple futuristic game and so I was off into Jarre
         land.... I purposely wrote the 2 melody lines to work off one voice to
         make it sound like more than 1 voice." (RH)
         The Last V8 was the first game released by Mastertronic's new label
         MAD (Mastertronic's Added Dimension). Due to the fact they wanted the
         launch to coincide with the release of the Last V8, the game was rush
         released and therefore unfortunately had a bug, where the
         main theme music (subtune #1) falls out of synch at around the one
         minute mark.  Upon closer investigation, this is due to a mere seven
         bytes of the music player code being incorrect.  This SID has those
         bytes corrected.

/Hubbard_Rob/Lightforce.sid
COMMENT: "Is LF a cover? I don't remember if it was. In any case it was good
         rythmically but the rest was a piece of junk." (RH)

  TITLE: Shibolet [from Audion]
 ARTIST: Synergy
COMMENT: "MOM was inspired from the Synergy album Audion." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Mega_Apocalypse_PSID.sid
COMMENT: Mega Apocalypse was the sequel to Crazy Comets. Music by Rob Hubbard,
         samples by Simon Nicol. Tunes #7 and #8 were sampled from the film
         "Star Wars". Mega Apocalypse was also the first C64 game to have three
         channel music and samples playing while you were playing the game.
         "I [...] think that Comets is much better than Mega A." (RH)
(#1)
  TITLE: Crazy Comets, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

/Hubbard_Rob/Monty_on_the_Run.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: The Devil's Gallop [from the Dick Barton radio show]
 ARTIST: Charles Williams
COMMENT: Heavily inspired by the song Devil's Gallop, which was the title theme
         for the 1940's American detective radio show "Dick Barton". "Monty
         [...] started out as the theme from the old radio detective show, Dick
         Barton" (RH, in the UK magazine "Popular Computing")
         "MOTR was supposed to be this run around like a madman type music and
         has lots of energy. The middle section was an excuse to use the new
         pitch bend code that I wrote for this project." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Nineteen.sid
  TITLE: 19
 ARTIST: Paul Hardcastle
COMMENT: RH actually wrote the music in 1987 but rumour has it that Cascade
         delayed the release of the game (subtitled with Part 1 'The Boot Camp'
         - Part 2 was never released) due to Ocean's Platoon coming out and
         being rather good - it eventually came out in June 1988. Also, copies
         of the game came with a free cassette single of the original Paul
         Hardcastle tune.

COMMENT: Cover of an American folk song.

/Hubbard_Rob/One_Man_and_His_Droid.sid
  TITLE: Space Game
COMMENT: This is a slightly adapted version of Final_Synth_Sample_II.sid tune
         #2. This tune was also used by Mastertronic as part of their
         "Invadeaload" tape loading game between 1988-91, which Rob knows
         nothing of whatsoever!
         "OMAHD was [...] Jarre inspired. It was actually based on something I
         wrote a few years before, so it was from music I had already written
         (as was Chimera and Phantoms of the Asteroids)." (RH)

         it.

         theme (/Hubbard_Rob/Warhawk.sid #1), specifically everything from 0:18
         onwards in the Warhawk theme. Warhawk was programmed by Proteus
         Developments, which explains the name.

/Hubbard_Rob/Ricochet.sid
COMMENT: Rob Hubbard was credited as Ample Hamble in this game, due to the
         strange sense of humor of the programmers who called themselves
         Gigglywurx.

/Hubbard_Rob/Ricochet_PSID.sid

         strange sense of humor of the programmers who called themselves
         Gigglywurx.

/Hubbard_Rob/Samantha_Fox_Strip_Poker.sid
COMMENT: Although the game clearly states that the music is by John York, it
         was really done by Rob Hubbard. Due to the 'tacky' nature of the game,
         Rob preferred not to have his name associated with it. According to
         Hubbard, it's his worst tune, anyway.
         "Sam Fox Strip Poker was such a cheesy title and they wanted that
         cheesy lame music along with it - I didn't want to admit that I did it
         just for the money !! John York was the first name that I thought of
         and used as an alias...." (RH)
(#9)
  TITLE: The Stripper
 ARTIST: David Rose
(#10)
  TITLE: The Entertainer
 ARTIST: Scott Joplin

/Hubbard_Rob/Sanxion.sid
COMMENT: "I think this has a bit of character about it. [...] Sanxion was a lot
         of fun, inspired by Zoolook by Jarre. Also Romeo and Juliet was used
         (not my idea but Gary Liddon's idea). I think most people remember the
         main theme. I think the solo is very melodic and is the best part of
         the tune...." (RH)
(#1)
   NAME: Thalamusik
COMMENT: "As I recall, the inspiration may have been about the time I bought
         Zoolook. There was only 2 tracks that I liked on that album. I think
         the synth solo in Sanxion is actually pretty melodic, even after all
         these years! I did do a much slower version on the Amiga once, but
         have no idea what ever happened to it."
(#2)
  TITLE: The Montagues and Capulets [from Romeo and Juliet]
 ARTIST: Sergey Prokofiev

 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard
COMMENT: See /Hubbard_Rob/Sanxion.sid #1.

  TITLE: Sigma Seven
 ARTIST: Julian Breeze
COMMENT: Hubbard covered the Spectrum version.

/Hubbard_Rob/Skate_or_Die_intro.sid
COMMENT: "The first thing I did for EA was Skate or Die C64." (RH)
         Many cracked versions of this game played this tune at the incorrect
         speed. This SID has been verified both by Rob Hubbard and against the
         original to be the correct speed of the tune.

/Hubbard_Rob/Skate_or_Die_intro_PSID.sid
COMMENT: "The first thing I did for EA was Skate or Die C64." (RH)
         Many cracked versions of this game played this tune at the incorrect
         speed. This SID has been verified both by Rob Hubbard and against the
         original to be the correct speed of the tune.

/Hubbard_Rob/Star_Paws.sid
COMMENT: "Star Paws was originally written for the Atari ST and was therefore
         compromised for that machine. The tune was basically junk - I was very
         tired and uninspired at the time."

/Hubbard_Rob/Thanatos.sid

 ARTIST: Julian Breeze

         "[Julian Breeze] gave me a music sketch and I implemented it... Never
         met or spoke with the chap." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Thing_on_a_Spring.sid
COMMENT: "Thing On A Spring was actually something I wrote to test my first
         driver."
         "TOAS never had it. So the middle section has nothing to do with the
         tune (bad). The 3rd section also has nothing to do with the tune but
         just fitted the tempo and feel so well...." (RH)

/Hubbard_Rob/Thrust.sid
COMMENT: Review copies of this game had a bugged loader which mucked up the
         music and so reviewers of the game gave the music a much lower rating.
         Julian Rignall (ex-editor of Zzap! 64) takes up the story:
         "I remember the God awful cacophony that was our review copy of
         Thrust's music as though it were still playing. This was the problem:
         the drum sounds worked, but all the other instrument sounds were
         screwed - basically it resulted in this horrible screeching noise
         playing to drums, rather than the cool heavyish sound that was heard
         in the final version of the game. It sounded really harsh and so it
         was duly shot down by us in the review. I remember hearing the
         'proper' version of the game at a later dater and thinking 'ooooops!'.
         After all it was a classic tune (it became one of my faves, indeed)
         and we'd mercilessly beaten it down in the review, which was totally
         unfair. Still, it was good to be able to do a ZZAPback on it and
         remedy the error."

/Hubbard_Rob/Up_Up_and_Away.sid

  TITLE: Up, Up, and Away
 ARTIST: Jimmy Webb
(#2)

 ARTIST: Ronnie Hilton

         expanded upon it greatly and took some big risks. It is too long.....
         I still have this idea about doing a custom version of this tune with
         synths etc..." (RH)

COMMENT: Also used in the game Space Killer.

 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard
COMMENT: This high score tune only plays if you enter your name as GO 159256.
         "This hidden tune was done as an easter egg with Stoat and Tim - just
         for a bit of fun. Those guys were kinda wacked out, back then." (RH)

         times from 2:15 and onwards.

/Hubbard_Rob/Zoids.sid

### /Huelsbeck_Chris #########################################################

/Huelsbeck_Chris/
COMMENT: Hülsbeck's own comments are denoted by (CH).
         More of Chris Hülsbeck's C64 music can be found in
         /Vaca_Ramiro/Startrash.sid & /Vaca_Ramiro/Turrican.sid.

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Axel_F.sid
  TITLE: Axel F [from the movie Beverly Hills Cop]
 ARTIST: Harold Faltermeyer

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Bad_Cat.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Passion (0:44)
 ARTIST: The Flirts
COMMENT: This is claimed to be the first ever C64 music made using samples.
         According to Hülsbeck, though, the game "Bad Cat" was delayed about 3
         months at Rainbow Arts during which time Imagine released their game
         "Arkanoid", containing Martin Galway's sample-like technique.
         "Arkanoid" thus became the first publically available game to feature
         SID music with samples.
         This is a cover from The Flirts's song Passion. The cover starts at
         0:44 with the same bass. At 1:14 you will hear the melody from
         Passion.
(#2)
COMMENT: A children's song when "nye-nye-nye-booh-booh, I was right!" :)
(#3)
COMMENT: Same as /Huelsbeck_Chris/Jinks.sid, Tune #12.

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Bad_Cat_PSID.sid
(#1)
COMMENT: This is claimed to be the first ever C64 music made using samples.
         According to Hülsbeck, though, the game "Bad Cat" was delayed about 3
         months at Rainbow Arts during which time Imagine released their game
         "Arkanoid", containing Martin Galway's sample-like technique.
         "Arkanoid" thus became the first publically available game to feature
         SID music with samples.
(#3)
COMMENT: Same as /Huelsbeck_Chris/Jinks_PSID.sid, Tune #12.

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Being_Boiled.sid
  TITLE: Being Boiled [from Reproduction]
 ARTIST: Phil Oakey/Ware/Marsh, Performed by Human League

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Circus_Attractions.sid
COMMENT: "There was some tune-swapping going on, as Chris was assigned [to do]
         the music for Circus Attractions while Ramiro had the pleasure of
         doing Rock'n'Roll. Now Chris hated circus music as much as Ramiro
         hated R'n'R. Therefore, Ramiro composed part of the Circus Attractions
         title music [and] Chris at some stage helped Ramiro with the R'n'R
         musics, but it is unclear in what way. [...]" (All info is from Miron
         Schmidt.)
(#1)
  TITLE: Entry of the Gladiators (0:00-0:17)
 ARTIST: Julius Fucik
  TITLE: Entry of the Gladiators (0:32-0:48)
 ARTIST: Julius Fucik

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Jinks.sid
(#2)
COMMENT: The title tune on the original C64 version would play in a different
         chord every time that the title screen was displayed. This is
         reproduced in some SID emulators by restarting the tune.

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Jinks_PSID.sid
(#2)
COMMENT: The title tune on the original C64 version would play in a different
         chord every time that the title screen was displayed. This is
         reproduced in some SID emulators by restarting the tune.

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Katakis.sid
COMMENT: According to an interview in a computer magazine, Manfred Trenz found
         the name Katago in a phone book of his hometown and the title for this
         game came from there.
         See /Huelsbeck_Chris/R-type.sid for further comments.
(#11)
  TITLE: Delta Force Title Theme [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Alan Silvestri

/Huelsbeck_Chris/R-type.sid
COMMENT: Very interesting story here. Katakis was released in September 1988 by
         Rainbow Arts, however it never got a release in the UK as Activision
         had it cancelled because of similarities to R-type, to which
         Activision had bought the conversion rights. Activision were getting
         nowhere with their conversion of R-Type and they liked what they saw
         of Katakis, so they hired the same programming team (Manfred Trenz and
         others) to do the C64 conversion. They only got 6 weeks to write the
         conversion, and sadly, it shows. Katakis was eventually altered and
         released as Denaris in 1989. Tunes #2 to #14 all cover of the arcade
         game.
(#2)
  TITLE: Scoring (High Score display) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#3)
  TITLE: Like a Hero (Game Complete) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#4)
  TITLE: Battle Theme (Stage 1) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#5)
  TITLE: Monster Beat (Stage 2) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#6)
  TITLE: Battle Pressure (Stage 3) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#7)
  TITLE: Butsu Butsuc<?> (Stage 4) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#8)
  TITLE: Stage 5 [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#9)
  TITLE: Scrambled Crossroad (Stage 6) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#10)
  TITLE: Ogorerumono wa Hisasikarasu (Stage 7) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#11)
  TITLE: Stage 8 [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
COMMENT: Only 0:00-0:16 appears to be a cover.
(#12)
  TITLE: Boss Theme (End of Level Boss BGM) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#13)
  TITLE: The End of a War (Game Over) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team
(#14)
  TITLE: Return in Triumph (Stage Clear) [from the arcade game R-type]
 ARTIST: Irem Sound Team

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Shades.sid
COMMENT: Aged 16, Chris Hülsbeck entered a music contest in the German computer
         magazine "64er Magazine" with this song. It finished #1. See
         /Huelsbeck_Chris/Shades_filter_corrected.sid for more information.

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Shades_filter_corrected.sid
COMMENT: "When I composed Shades, I had a slightly out of whack filter in my
         C64 and I didn't have the time to cross-check with other C64s. Result
         is that the tune appears too filtered compared to my original
         intention. I released a little program to correct the filter in the
         next magazine edition after the competition. Here is a version that is
         much closer to how it was intended to sound." (CH)

/Huelsbeck_Chris/Ski_Dance.sid
  TITLE: Ski Dance [from the movie Fire & Ice]
 ARTIST: Gary Wright

### /JCH/ ####################################################################

/JCH/
COMMENT: All comments to JCH's tunes are, unless stated, his own.

/JCH/2cVee.sid
COMMENT: Experimental tune with music in 2 voices and 9 sfx in the third voice.
         This was the first time I ever did this.
         Composed in JCH player v3.

/JCH/42nd_Street.sid
COMMENT: A very weird tune with a very weird ending. After I named the tune
         "42nd Street" I played it in a driver on the C64 which could display
         the time - and to my surprise it lasted exactly 42 seconds.
         Composed in JCH player v9, tune length is 0:42.

/JCH/Abstract_1.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v08.03, tune length is 0:24.

/JCH/Accident.sid
COMMENT: Cooperation between Morten Sigaard Kristensen and I. The bass was
         taken from a pophit and I made the rest on top of it.
         Composed in JCH player v14, tune length is 1:56.

/JCH/Acid_1988.sid
COMMENT: Made in 1988 but packed and released several years later.
         Composed in JCH player v6, tune length is 0:51.

/JCH/Ages.sid
COMMENT: This was one of the first tunes I entirely made on the keyboard before
         bonging it into the editor. Normally, most music was composed directly
         on the computer without the aid of a synthesizer keyboard.
         Composed in JCH player v17.G1, tune length is 0:30.

/JCH/Aliensong.sid
COMMENT: Was used in the game Extreme, (c) 1991 O. Heicke & Jochen E.
         Composed in JCH player v13.

/JCH/Aouw.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v10, tune length is 0:57.

/JCH/Batman_long.sid
COMMENT: This is probably the most popular tune I ever made.
         Composed in JCH player v10, tune length is 4:52.

/JCH/Batman_short.sid
COMMENT: Shorter version of the popular Batman tune without the slow part in
         the beginning. See "Batman_long.sid" for more information.
         Composed in JCH player v10, tune length is 3:14.

/JCH/Beatbassie.sid
COMMENT: Although very simple, this tune became quite popular.
         Composed in JCH player v01.13, tune length is 2:13.

/JCH/Better_late_than_never.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH digiplayer, tune length is 0:15.
         The first digi tune I've ever composed. I never tried "Rock Monitor"
         or any other editor before this.

/JCH/Better_late_than_nevr_PSID.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH digiplayer, tune length is 0:15.
         The first digi tune I've ever composed. I never tried "Rock Monitor"
         or any other editor before this.

/JCH/Bill_Bass.sid
COMMENT: "DRAX" did most of the work composing the bass, drums and chords and I
         did the leader.
         Composed in JCH player v15.G6, tune length is 0:17.

/JCH/Bitter.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v8, tune length is 3:24.

/JCH/Blizzard.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v14, tune length is 1:02.

/JCH/Bones_plus.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v9.

/JCH/Bonzai_3.sid
COMMENT: After trying to make the SID-chip say "Triangle" I tried to make it
         say "Bonzai". Not my most successful speech emulation to date,
         however.
         Composed in JCH player v17.G1, tune length is 0:06.

/JCH/Brubaker.sid
COMMENT: This was made for an adventure game ordered by a german demogroup. The
         game itself was never finished. (According to MAD, the game WAS
         finished, but JCH was never told about it.)
         Composed in JCH player v17.Q0, tune length is 4:21.

/JCH/Buuhuu.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v15.G5, tune length is 0:23.

/JCH/Calypso.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v15.G1, tune length is 0:07.

/JCH/Carcrash.sid
COMMENT: The name refers to the ring modulation effect which sounds like a car
         screeching to its doom.
         Composed in JCH player v9, tune length is 2:49.

/JCH/Casio.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v14.G0, tune length is 0:34.

/JCH/Cause_I_Love_Her_So.sid
COMMENT: A worktune where I imagined the words above "sung" to the notes from
         14-30 seconds of play. The part from 00:30 was later extracted to form
         the release song "Real_Shit.sid".
         Composed in JCH player v05.02.

/JCH/Caveman.sid
COMMENT: Another cooperation between Morten Sigaard Kristensen and I.
         Composed in JCH player v15, tune length is 1:42.

/JCH/Caverns.sid

/JCH/Chord_1.sid
COMMENT: Tune using only two voices.
         Composed in JCH player v08.02, tune length is 0:40.

/JCH/Chordian.sid
COMMENT: This tune was sent to a guy in England who promised to use it in a
         game with credits by Vibrants. However, it seems as if he liked it so
         much that he put his very own credits on the game...
         (Ed.) The game is named Stack Up (1991 by Zeppelin Games) and the guy
         is Gerard 'Gez' Gourley/Sonic Graffity.
         Composed in JCH player v15, tune length is 4:05.

/JCH/Coops_Ups.sid
COMMENT: Here Morten Sigaard Kristensen managed to make most of the tune and
         then "invited" me to do the solo in the end of it.
         Composed in JCH player v20, tune length is 1:17.

/JCH/Cotune_2.sid
COMMENT: A cooperation tune "DRAX" and I tried to do. He did the bass, drums
         and chords and I tried to do the leader. I soon ran out of inspiration
         and the tune was never finished.
         Composed in JCH player v13.G0, tune length is 1:52.

/JCH/Craptune.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v12, tune length is 0:38.

/JCH/Crowdnoise.sid
COMMENT: The last sound I ever did on the C64, made July 1992. At that time I
         had been away from the C64 for months, playing around with the PC -
         however, a guy in "Pretzel Logic" said he needed a crowdnoise effect,
         so I did it. The demo he worked on was AFAIK never released.
         Composed in JCH player v20.

/JCH/Dandelion.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v17.G1, tune length is 0:07.

/JCH/Demogame_example.sid
COMMENT: This block was made as the first of seven planned leveltunes. It was
         ordered by a guy in "Bonzai", shortly after I met "Trap" of "Bonzai"
         for the first time. This was the second attempt after the "Golddigger"
         project. The game was never finished.
(#1)
   NAME: Get Ready
(#2)
   NAME: Game Over
(#3)
   NAME: Player explodes
(#4)
   NAME: Congratulations/Title
(#5)
   NAME: In-Game

/JCH/Diflexing.sid
COMMENT: Made at Jewels' place. I tried to emulate the style of Diflex as heard
         in his "Strike Force" tunes.
         (This tune was used in a game titled "Soccer 7".)
         Composed in JCH player v4, tune length is 1:47.

/JCH/Dogshit.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v17.G1, tune length is 0:15.

/JCH/Dont_be_sad.sid
COMMENT: The first 30 seconds was "inspired" by an Amiga song I found in a new
         tracker on that computer.
         Composed in JCH player v5.

/JCH/Double_speed.sid
COMMENT: This is the only quickspeed tune not made in v17.Q0. It was made in
         1989, some time before Jeroen Tel made his first quatro-tune for
         "Invest". However, the idea was not new at that time. In the
         mid-eighties Tony Crowther experimented with quatro players in games
         such as "Zig Zag". My double speed tune, however, used the ordinary v9
         player and was simply called twice a frame.
         Composed in JCH player v9.

/JCH/Duchesse.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v13, tune length is 2:18.

/JCH/Easy_does_it.sid
COMMENT: Notice how I put real synthesizer chords into the digi voice. That was
         not done very often on the Commodore 64 - musicians normally used this
         channel for bass and drums only. The tune makes extensive use of ring
         modulation effects and was used in a "Pretzel Logic" demo.
         Composed in JCH digiplayer, tune length is 2:02.

/JCH/Easy_does_it_PSID.sid
COMMENT: Notice how I put real synthesizer chords into the digi voice. That was
         not done very often on the Commodore 64 - musicians normally used this
         channel for bass and drums only. The tune makes extensive use of ring
         modulation effects and was used in a "Pretzel Logic" demo.
         Composed in JCH digiplayer, tune length is 2:02.

/JCH/Farting.sid
COMMENT: Thrown together in a few minutes to show a friend how to use the
         editor.
         Composed in JCH player v5, tune length is 0:45.

/JCH/Feel_it.sid
COMMENT: Another tune that was packed and released at a much later date.
         Composed in JCH player v6, tune length is 0:51.

/JCH/Fiasko_2.sid
COMMENT: This was in fact the first suggestion to the "Oswald" game. I played
         the tune to the programmer and graphician of the game but they didn't
         like it. They loved the next attempt however, which you can find as
         "Super_Oswald.sid".
         Composed in JCH player v10.G1, tune length is 0:24.

/JCH/Forever_Cry.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v13, tune length is 1:22.

/JCH/George_Carl.sid
COMMENT: A long tune containing three completely different parts. The slow
         introduction changes at 01:19 to a part which was played by the clown
         George Carl during his shows. Here I tried to emulate a real mouth
         organ using ring modulation.
         Composed in JCH player v13.

/JCH/Glider_Pilot.sid
  TITLE: Glider Pilot
 ARTIST: <?>
COMMENT: This was a conversion from an old C64 game of the same name. The
         composition was very nice but used horribly raw sounds. I converted
         the tune and it was used in the demo that won the C64 demo competition
         at the Randers copy-party. The original is in the HVSC as
         /GAMES/G-L/Glider_Pilot.sid.
         Composed in JCH player v10, tune length is 0:51.

/JCH/Going_Up.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v15, tune length is 0:30.

/JCH/Golddigger.sid
COMMENT: This was the first real game-music project I did. It was planned as a
         cooperation between Link and I after meeting each other for the first
         time in february 1989. The music itself was supposed to have been used
         for a "Boulder Dash" clone, but the Danish software house "The New
         Electronic Generation" did not survive its first game.

/JCH/Guldkornekspressen_Lvls_v3.sid
COMMENT: This and the next block contains all five leveltunes crammed together
         in one single block. Notice (3) in the block which is a conversion of
         the music "Do the Locomotion" - I thought it would be a nice touch to
         such a train game. However, SilverRock thought they might get in
         trouble if I converted it, so... (See comment for
         /JCH/Guldkornekspressen_Lvls_v4.sid.)
         Composed in JCH player v17.
(#3)
  TITLE: Loco-Motion
 ARTIST: Little Eva
COMMENT: Based on the version sung by Kylie Minogue.

/JCH/Guldkornekspressen_Lvls_v4.sid
COMMENT: (Continued from /JCH/Guldkornekspressen_Lvls_v3.sid) ...this is how it
         was changed to make SilverRock happy. As you can hear, the difference
         is really not that big. Later on during the programming of the game,
         Thomas (the programmer) realized that he could not fit all the
         leveltunes into the game, hence this leveltune was the first to go.
         Composed in JCH player v17.
(#3)
  TITLE: Do The Locomotion
 ARTIST: Little Eva
COMMENT: Based on the version sung by Kylie Minogue.

/JCH/Hacktrick.sid
COMMENT: My friend, "The Saint", hummed the bassline and I made all the rest.
         Composed in JCH player v11, tune length is 1:01.

/JCH/Hard_On.sid
COMMENT: The first song done in a player featuring "Hard restart" - so as you
         see, the name is not as naughty as you might think! ;)
         Composed in JCH player v11, tune length is 0:30.

/JCH/Hawaii.sid
COMMENT: A very long tune containing one of the longest solo parts I have ever
         done in a C64 tune. The bassline and drums were originally made by
         Morten Sigaard Kristensen, but in the end I "raped" it so much that it
         virtually became my own work. The solo part starts at 01:39. Notice
         how the tune decays in the end - this was very unusual on the C64.
         Composed in JCH player v15.

/JCH/Heavy_Hit.sid
COMMENT: Short, "end-of-level-monster"-like tune made in a compromise player
         which took VERY little rastertime.
         Composed in JCH player v19, tune length is 1:01.

/JCH/Hexagon_Party.sid
COMMENT: Made FOR that party, not AT it. The tune contains quite a lot of
         harmonic mistakes, something I often made in that period. These were
         often caused by "lazy" transpositions of the bassline sequence -
         instead of creating a new one.
         Composed in JCH player v2, tune length is 3:43.

/JCH/Highscore.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v05.02, tune length is 0:31.

COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v9, tune length is 0:57.

         tune length is 2:09.

/JCH/Labyrint.sid
COMMENT: A television quiz program which was made popular by a great Danish
         former disc-jockey Kim Schumacher was converted by a small Danish firm
         as a C64 game. The music was composed on the Amiga by an unknown guy.
         "DRAX" was asked to convert the tune for a certain sum of money but,
         as he said himself, he wasn't sure he could convert it so he asked me
         for help. I completed the conversion for the ridiculous sum of money.
         Later, "DRAX" admitted that he didn't complete the conversion because
         he thought the original Amiga music was boring. I must confess that he
         has a point there.
         Tune length is 2:09.

/JCH/Lady_Lisa.sid
COMMENT: This tune was composed and then put on ice, only to be packed and
         released at a much later date.
         Composed in JCH player v17, tune length is 0:31.

/JCH/Leech.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v9, tune length is 1:12.

/JCH/Little_Test.sid
COMMENT: The second tune I did after "Better late than never". Most samples
         were sampled from the Korg M1 using Commodore's own hardware sampler
         which plugged into the cartridge port. It makes VERY extensive use of
         ring modulation and hard sync.
         Composed in JCH digiplayer, tune length is 1:55.

/JCH/Little_Test_PSID.sid
COMMENT: The second tune I did after "Better late than never". Most samples
         were sampled from the Korg M1 using Commodore's own hardware sampler
         which plugged into the cartridge port. It makes VERY extensive use of
         ring modulation and hard sync.
         Composed in JCH digiplayer, tune length is 1:55.

         awkward to use any further.

/JCH/Louisiana.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v12.

/JCH/Maduplec3.sid
COMMENT: It is a slow tune - today, I actually think it sounds best if you play
         it a THREE times the speed in SidPlay instead of the usual TWO. It has
         nothing to do with "Maduplec" from "Buds" other than the name itself.
         Composed in JCH player v17.Q0.
(#1)
COMMENT: This tune is played at the original 2x speed.
(#2)
COMMENT: This tune is the same as tune #1, but is played at 3x speed.

/JCH/Maniac_Mansion.sid
  TITLE: Maniac Mansion, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Chris Grigg & David Lawrence
COMMENT: I was impressed with the titletune on "Maniac Mansion", an adventure
         game by LucasFilm (that was years before they changed their name to
         LucasArts). However, the instruments were rubbish so I did my very own
         version of it. At a silent part in the end of the tune I even added a
         few notes of my own.
         Composed in JCH player v5, tune length is 1:37.

/JCH/Maniaxion.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v17, tune length is 1:57.
         Later used in the titlescreen of the game Pitfighter, (c) 1991 Domark.

/JCH/Martin_4.sid
COMMENT: Apart from using the drumset from the "Batman"-tune, I experimented
         with the pulse Martin Galway made in the "Rambo" highscore tune.
         Composed in JCH player v10.G1.

/JCH/Memory_I.sid
COMMENT: Even though it was composed in the same month as where the editor was
         finished, it was put on ice only to be properly packed and released
         some years later.
         Composed in JCH player v5.

/JCH/Michelle.sid
COMMENT: Another two-in-one tune, one of the better of that period. Especially
         the last part is IMHO still nice.

/JCH/Modemtrading.sid

         carefully you can hear a telephone ringing - followed by a modem
         connecting.

/JCH/Ode_to_JO.sid
COMMENT: Made after I heard one of JO's terrific "hard restart" songs. I was
         impressed with the way his ADSR worked on his chord sounds, so I tried
         to do the same thing. However, I didn't really know what it was until
         JO told me how it was done. I then implemented it from player v11.
         Composed in JCH player v9, tune length is 1:09.

         composed in the titletune for the game. At the time of doing the music
         for the game, I thought it would be a nice touch if a main theme could
         be heard throughout the game - just like in the movies! :)

COMMENT: The end-of-game congratulations tune.

/JCH/Orcus_dark_lord.sid
COMMENT: Probably the only tune I ever did in three-four time on the C64.
         Composed in JCH player v12.

/JCH/Orcus_funk_level.sid
COMMENT: A funky piece using four-fingered chords, something that I rarely used
         on the C64.
         Composed in JCH player v12.

/JCH/Orcus_giv_it_up.sid
COMMENT: Funny tune with a ring modulation experiment. If you listen closely,
         you can hear it say "Give it up" - I thought it would be a nice touch
         while shooting down enemies in the game. The ring modulation effects
         appears from 00:16.
         Composed in JCH player v12.

/JCH/Orcus_guitaring.sid
COMMENT: Here I used filtering on the leader to emulate a real guitar. The EOLM
         tune is a very funny "major" version. Imagine a bizarre monster which
         looks like a clown. That tune is a conversion of a song which my
         brother and I used to hum when we were kids...
         Composed in JCH player v12.

/JCH/Orcus_klingonzo.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v12.

/JCH/Orcus_loader.sid
COMMENT: A very weird theme for the tape loader - it uses parts of the same
         composition as found in the titletune.
         Composed in JCH player v17.

/JCH/Pheric.sid
COMMENT: A tune using filtering in two voices which was not very common on the
         C64. The tune was packed and released at a much later date.
         Composed in JCH player v6, tune length is 1:32.

/JCH/Pit_Fighter.sid
COMMENT: One of the last game projects I worked on. Through the member in
         Scotland, "Deek", I made contact with a guy who managed to get me a
         few orders from the software house "Domark". This music was ordered
         for "Pit Fighter". It was probably in 1991 - I remember I made an
         extra effort out of squeezing as many chords and effects into the two
         voices of the ingame tune as I could, to make it sound like many more
         voices. Composed in JCH player v17.
(#1)
   NAME: Bonus
(#2)
   NAME: Ingame

/JCH/Pit_Pot.sid
  TITLE: Pit Pot
 ARTIST: <?>
COMMENT: Conversion from a game cartridge on the 8-bit SEGA. Sometimes it was
         difficult to hear all the details which made me go for certain
         compromises - something I was too inexperienced to handle properly at
         that time...
         Composed in JCH player v2, tune length is 1:02.

/JCH/Push-It.sid
COMMENT: The Danish demogroup "Jewels" also fiddled with a puzzle game, called
         "Push-It". This is the intro tune, one of my favourite tunes from the
         C64 period. It uses a double voice drum and was heavily inspired by
         the music from "Task III". The game itself was never finished. You may
         have to fiddle with filter parameters to make that snare drum sound
         the way it should.
         Composed in JCH player v13.

COMMENT: Here's the main music block for "Push-It", the puzzle game. It was
         made in november 1989.

/JCH/Real_Good.sid
COMMENT: Named so because I liked the result when I made it in 1988/1989. I
         remember I was so disappointed when I learned that "Einstein" of
         "Upfront" didn't like it.
         Composed in JCH player v6.

/JCH/Real_Shit.sid
COMMENT: Actually extracted from a worktune called "Cause I Love Her So". I
         liked the start of the worktune but I thought this part didn't really
         belong so I extracted it to form a separate song and made a lot of
         fast solo's on top of it.
         Composed in JCH player v8, tune length is 3:02.

/JCH/Revenge.sid
COMMENT: Here I deliberately tried to put together a lot of chords in a song
         which shifts in and out of the minor and major scales.
         Composed in JCH player v15.

COMMENT: This was the first tune done in the final editor, hence the name.
         Composed in JCH player v5, tune length is 1:01.

         tune "Hoppin'".
         Composed in JCH player v1.

/JCH/Secret_Land.sid

/JCH/Shadow_Sun.sid
COMMENT: This was one of the last tunes I composed in an assembler listing. My
         editor was almost complete and after trying it, I never wanted to
         compose music in assembler again.
         Composed in JCH player v5, tune length is 1:01.

/JCH/Shes_Just_A_Maniac.sid
COMMENT: A tune where I tried to emulate the style of Maniacs of Noise. As the
         title suggests, parts of the notes matches the words so you can
         actually sing the title to it. Try it after 9-12 seconds of play! :)
         Composed in JCH player v4, tune length is 1:11.

/JCH/Shift.sid
COMMENT: A worktune that wasn't finished. Due to the fact that we have reached
         1991, my Korg M1 was a reality. This tune was totally composed on the
         keyboard first, apart from the digi voice which was added later using
         the editor alone. The digi voice doesn't appear until 01:16 - it was
         supposed to be a "surprise" tune. This was also the last digital tune
         I did - and as far as I can remember, the very last C64 tune as well.
         Composed in JCH digiplayer, tune length is 2:33.

/JCH/Shift_PSID.sid
COMMENT: A worktune that wasn't finished. Due to the fact that we have reached
         1991, my Korg M1 was a reality. This tune was totally composed on the
         keyboard first, apart from the digi voice which was added later using
         the editor alone. The digi voice doesn't appear until 01:16 - it was
         supposed to be a "surprise" tune. This was also the last digital tune
         I did - and as far as I can remember, the very last C64 tune as well.
         Composed in JCH digiplayer, tune length is 2:33.

/JCH/Simple_tune.sid

/JCH/Skaermtrolden_Hugo.sid
  TITLE: Hugo Rap Theme
 ARTIST: <?>
COMMENT: A professional software house in Denmark called "SilverRock" gained a
         lot of success with "Hugo" in danish television. This troll could be
         controlled in a game using telephone buttons. A very new concept which
         soon became enormously popular. During the success of the troll, a
         real musician produced a CD containing a rap hit where Hugo was
         singing using the typical voice which was also used in the game. As
         the game was converted for sales versions from the Amiga to PC and
         C64, I did the C64 song converted from the Danish rap hit.
         Composed in JCH player v17, tune length is 1:24.

/JCH/Slapbass.sid
COMMENT: A long tune based on a slapbass. The result doesn't really sound like
         a slapbass, but I couldn't get any closer at the time. Some years
         later, a Dutch guy proved that by using the $51 waveform, you COULD
         get quite close indeed!
         Composed in JCH player v9.

/JCH/Soft_3.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v14.G0.

/JCH/Song_made_in_monitor.sid
COMMENT: The only tune I ever did in a machinecode monitor. I knew that Laxity
         made all his music this way and I wanted to try it out. Although I
         managed to compose a tune, I didn't like the method at all.
         Composed in JCH player v01.13, tune length is 0:30.

/JCH/Spaceport.sid
  TITLE: Spaceport [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Holger Gehrmann
COMMENT: Conversion from the titletune of an old "reLINE" game on the Amiga -
         one of my friends asked me if I would convert it.
         Composed in JCH player v13, tune length is 1:21.

         "Su-Sweet". I was contacted and asked to do the soundtrack within a
         very tight deadline. This is the music for the game - it was done in
         march 1991.

/JCH/Super_Oswald.sid
COMMENT: Before inventing "Hugo" for television, SilverRock Productions
         actually had a little success with its predecessor, "Oswald", which
         was also controlled using an ordinary telephone.
         Composed in JCH player v10.

/JCH/Sweet_2.sid
COMMENT: One of the tunes I really should have completed.
         Composed in JCH player v06.01, tune length is 0:51.

/JCH/Tecnetium.sid
COMMENT: I always get mixed feelings when I play this music. The title- tune is
         long and I put a lot of work into it in april 1989, but today I can
         hear loads of harmonic errors here and there. The game was done for a
         sideways shoot'em up which a couple of totally unknown danish guys was
         making. They soon lost all interest in their game, however. The
         hiscore theme was a conversion of the old Cliff Richard hit
         "Congratulations" done right out my head. I always wanted to make such
         a hiscore tune, because I always thought Rob Hubbard did it all wrong
         when he made "sad" hiscore tunes. It is a sad thing when the game
         ends, but getting a high score is supposed to be a GOOD thing! :)
(#1)
   NAME: Title Screen
(#2)
  TITLE: Congratulations
 ARTIST: Cliff Richard

/JCH/Termianal.sid
COMMENT: A short cooperation between Morten Sigaard Kristensen and I. As usual
         he did the bass and drums and I did the leader and chords.
         Composed in JCH player v15, tune length is 1:22.

/JCH/Terrible.sid
COMMENT: Test done in the compromise player v19.G1 which has no vibrato routine
         at all.
         Composed in JCH player v19.G1, tune length is 0:12.

/JCH/Test_04_3.sid
COMMENT: The last tune I did in player v04 for the sequence-less editor. This
         tune is very interesting due to the fact that I actually composed the
         chords on a keyboard, something that was very unusual in this period.
         Composed in JCH player v04.13, tune length is 0:38.

/JCH/Ultraefficient.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v8, tune length is 1:26.

/JCH/Voices_1-3_of_6.sid
COMMENT: During my time of composing music I managed to own a C64 and a C128 at
         the same time. Naturally I just had to try the old experiment where
         both computers are playing, echo detuning the music. This gave me the
         idea of composing three voices on each computer to make 6 voices of
         C64 music. This is the bass and drums part.
         Composed in JCH player v17.G1, tune length is 0:07.

/JCH/Voices_4-6_of_6.sid
COMMENT: This is the chords part of the 6-voice experiment.
         Composed in JCH player v17.G1, tune length is 0:07.

/JCH/Volvulus.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v10, tune length is 3:24.

COMMENT: My first attempt at making an "end-of-level-monster"-ditty.
         Composed in JCH player v05.02, tune length is 0:17.

/JCH/Weirdest.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v15.G6, tune length is 0:08.

/JCH/Weirdo.sid
COMMENT: A "neverending" tune where the tracks does not have the same length.
         The two chord voices are therefore misaligned every time the tune
         restarts.
         Composed in JCH player v14, tune length is 0:30.

/JCH/Westend_Girls.sid
  TITLE: West End Girls
 ARTIST: Pet Shop Boys
COMMENT: Probably one of the worst tunes I have ever done.
         Composed in JCH player v2, tune length is 0:22.

/JCH/Who_said_Fred_Grey.sid
COMMENT: Very funny tune where I tried to emulate the weird "pulsating" Fred
         Grey used to have in his tunes where the pulse was changed for each
         note but not during the note. As to whether I managed to match his
         style or not - well, judge for yourself! :)
         Composed in JCH player v17.G1, tune length is 0:12.

/JCH/Why.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v6, tune length is 1:35.

/JCH/Wizax_demo.sid
COMMENT: The first tune to use the "testbit-noise" technique which locks and
         unlocks the noise in such a way that the noise waveform sounds more
         metallic. However, I later discovered that this worked differently
         from C64 to C64. On some C64, I had to lock the waveform with $F0,
         where other versions required $F8 to achieve the same effect.
         Composed in JCH player v5.

/JCH/Wizax_intro.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v2, tune length is 1:01.

/JCH/X-Mas_Zak.sid
COMMENT: Composed in JCH player v17.G1, tune length is 0:30.

/JCH/X-Ray.sid
COMMENT: A trick introtune based on the idea of having a simple long filter
         tone in very short intro's on the C64. I got this idea of playing such
         a tone for some seconds, suddenly surprising everyone with a piece of
         music.
         Composed in JCH player v6, tune length is 1:26.

/JCH/Zippy_Race_Traverse_USA.sid
COMMENT: Conversion of the music from the arcade game of the same name. It was
         also known as "Traverse USA". I happened to own an arcade machine
         hooked up to an Amiga monitor, and this was one of the "cards" I had.
         Composed in JCH player v10.G1.
(#1)
COMMENT: 2-voice ingame tune
(#2)
COMMENT: 2-voice "GO!" ditty

### /JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer ###################################################

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Alpha_Centauri.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 7:04.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Back_to_Alpha_Centauri.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player 10.10, tune length is 6:04.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Beaty_intro.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player v10, tune length is 0:15.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Big_Bad_X-Mas.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 6:14.
  TITLE: Nu är det jul igen (0:00)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: Swedish Christmas song.
  TITLE: White Christmas (0:25)
 ARTIST: Irving Berlin
  TITLE: Jingle Bells (1:25)
 ARTIST: James Pierpont
  TITLE: Två små röda luvor och en fårskinnsfäll (2:47)
 ARTIST: Arild Feldborg, Karin Vollgast
COMMENT: Swedish Christmas song.
  TITLE: Rudolph The Red Nosed Reindeer (3:34)
 ARTIST: Johnny Marks
  TITLE: Stille Nacht! Heilige Nacht! (5:04-6:14)
 ARTIST: Joseph Mohr (lyrics), Franz Xaver Grüber (music)

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Birthday.sid
COMMENT: A birthday song made for the Jewels demogroup. They were celebrating
         their group and wanted such a tune. The birthday tune in the beginning
         might be a Danish song.
         Composed in Laxity's player, tune length is 2:35.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Cant_Stop.sid
COMMENT: An introtune which became very popular in the United States.
         Composed in Laxity's player, tune length is 0:30.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Classic_Rhythms.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 8:08.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Darkness_III.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player 9.1, tune length is 0:51.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Darkness_IV.sid
COMMENT: The last song I did in the old player system. Also the only one not
         composed in Aegis Sonix, it was done in Sound Tracker on Amiga - yes,
         one of the first versions from Karsten Obarski. It was still converted
         using the old awkward system though.
         Composed in old JCH player 10.10, tune length is 4:43.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Dreaming.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player 9.1, tune length is 4:38.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Drum-demo.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player 9.1, tune length is 0:25

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Experiment_6.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player 10.10, tune length is 0:04.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Experiment_6_v2.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player 10.10, tune length is 0:04.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Five_Minutes.sid
COMMENT: As the name suggests it was done in a hurry on Aegis Sonix.
         Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 0:51.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Fooled.sid
COMMENT: Introtune made in an experimental player called "Intro Player". The
         player took very little rastertime but suffered under too many
         compromises. I only made this tune in the player.
         Composed in JCH Introplayer, tune length is 0:51.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Gotta_Hurry_Up.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 2:09.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Gunfight.sid
COMMENT: I managed to code a complete Gunfight game in 1987-1988 - you know,
         the stuff with two gunfighters in each side of the screen shooting
         each other until one of them enters "BOOT HILL". This tune was made in
         "Aegis Sonix" - the only tune to be converted using the old method
         into Laxity's player.
         Composed in Laxity's player, tune length is 1:32.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Heavy_Thing.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 2:45.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/I_Miss_You.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 3:30.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Illegal_Man.sid
COMMENT: After the music group "20CC" had been in the demo scene for some time,
         a sourcecode was hacked and spread on the american BBS. I managed to
         get a version of this sourcecode - and tried to fiddle with it. This
         is what came out of it. It was composed in assembler and changes after
         15 seconds.
         Composed in 20CC player, tune length is 1:47.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/James_Bond_Theme.sid
  TITLE: James Bond Theme [from the James Bond series of movies]
 ARTIST: Monty Norman
COMMENT: Conversion of a 007 theme found on a CD containing James Bond
         synthesizer conversions.
         Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 1:14.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Jewels.sid
  TITLE: Wouldn't It Be Good [from Human Racing]
 ARTIST: Nik Kershaw
COMMENT: Conversion of an old Nik Kershaw song. The first version of the old
         player to feature slide. Many of the tunes in this period didn't use
         any slide at all.
         Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 1:33.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/L_L_L.sid
COMMENT: The first tune made in Laxity's. Not 100% my own composition since I
         left parts of the instruments and bassline intact (try to compare it
         with /Laxity/Ikari_Intro_Song.sid).
         Composed in Laxity's player, tune length is 0:53.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Last_One.sid
COMMENT: The last tune I made in Laxity's player until Laxity told me to stop
         using his player. I then began coding a new player system and later an
         editor as well.
         Composed in Laxity's player, tune length is 3:42.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Mad4.sid
COMMENT: Maduplec of "BUDS", a very prominent coder in the demo scene became
         quite an alrounder in the later C64 days. Making close to everything
         himself he painted the graphics, coded, composed and even made a music
         editor with his own player. He sent me a version of it to me for
         testing, and this is the result. The player takes very little
         rastertime. I remember that when I sent him the tune he told me it was
         "typically me".
         Composed in Maduplec's player, tune length is 1:32.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Mayday_v3.sid
  TITLE: Stranded in Iowa
 ARTIST: Manfred Mann
COMMENT: Parts of the song was actually inspired by an old Manfred Mann song
         called "Stranded in Iowa".
         Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 6:45.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Moonlight.sid
COMMENT: This is the very first song I ever composed. It happened on Aegis
         Sonix on the Amiga. I remember I was very proud - today, I wonder
         why...
         Composed in old JCH player.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Need_You_Tonight_v1.sid
  TITLE: Need You Tonight [from Kick]
 ARTIST: INXS
COMMENT: Conversion of the old Inxs hit. Later in 1989 I made another attempt
         because the demogroup Jewels wanted a better conversion.
         Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 2:36.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/No_Birthday.sid
COMMENT: Shorter version of "Birthday" without the silly birthday song in the
         beginning.
         Composed in Laxity's player, tune length is 2:18.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Ode_to_the_64.sid
COMMENT: I tried to make a tune like Rob Hubbard's "One Man and his Droid", but
         the result was not too brilliant.
         Composed in old JCH player 6.4, tune length is 2:56.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Orion_Copy-Party.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 2:50.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Paw_Music_v2.sid
COMMENT: An introtune. The part from 00:20 was really a small excerpt from my
         "Alpha Centauri".
         Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 1:12.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Quick_Blast.sid
COMMENT: One of the better tunes in the period with the old player system. It
         was also the first tune to contain the typical "Hubbard"-snare which
         was a mixture of noise and triangle, swapped at each frame.
         Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 3:32.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Reincarnations.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player 10.10, tune length is 7:36.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Schh.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player 5, tune length is 2:47.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/September.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 3:42.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Sharks_game.sid
COMMENT: The only real gametrack in the old player, containing 4 tunes. It was
         ordered by a German democoder (Typhus of Inxs) but was never used.
         Composed in old JCH player 9.1.
(#1)
COMMENT: Titletune
(#2)
COMMENT: Ingame
(#3)
COMMENT: Hiscore
(#4)
COMMENT: Jingle

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Sorry.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 3:34.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Speedy_Gun.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 2:30.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Train.sid
COMMENT: Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 2:38.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Typhus_1.sid
COMMENT: This is the only tune I did in Future Composer, made at the Dexion
         copy-party in 1988, the same party where I was told by Laxity to keep
         my hands off his player. The Future Composer was a hack editor on
         Charles Deenen's player and it arrived at this party for the first
         time. I tried it out once - and never touched it again. "Typhus" was
         the name of the german guy who also ordered the "Sharks" music in the
         old player.
         Composed in Future Composer, tune length is 0:46.

/JCH/Non_JCH_Newplayer/Yoko_Tsuno.sid
COMMENT: Has nothing to do with the cartoon character by Roger Leloup as such,
         only that I was quite fond of that cartoon at that time.
         Composed in old JCH player, tune length is 1:16.

### /Joseph_Richard ##########################################################

/Joseph_Richard/Barbarian.sid
COMMENT: "Conan? Yes - Steve Brown wanted it like the films.(Red Sonya, too) It
         was hard to get the 64 sounding like a Conan movie!!! The reviewers
         gave me a bad time for doing that music, but I liked it myself - o
         well..." (RJ)

         the Wimbledon tennis tournament.

/Leitch_Barry/Hillstreet.sid
  TITLE: Hill Street Blues theme [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: Mike Post

/Leitch_Barry/I_C_U_P_S.sid
  TITLE: Hoodoo Voodoo
 ARTIST: Graham Marsh (BOGG)
COMMENT: "Icups - my first published work... I had written the tune as a demo,
         and I had been trading with Bogg for a few years, and I had re-written
         his tune just to see how I would have taken his initial idea and run
         with it myself. Anyways, I had sent disks with a load of tunes on to
         all the major software companies at the time. Firebird contacted me,
         they wanted to use Icups. I told them at the time that it was kind of
         a rip off of Bogg's Detergent, but they were quite happy to offer to
         buy it. They offered me 150 pounds, and then when someone pointed out
         again to them that it was based on Bogg's tune, they gave him half the
         money too which I was quite happy with." (BL)

/Leitch_Barry/If_I_Was.sid
  TITLE: If I Was [from Answers To Nothing]
 ARTIST: Midge Ure

/Leitch_Barry/Impossamole.sid
  TITLE: Monty on the Run, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard
COMMENT: Due to a bug in the game code, when the game switched from the title
         screen to the high score table, it placed forty or so incorrect bytes
         into the music routine, making the theme tune bug and play one of the
         voices at the wrong pitch. Leitch has confirmed that this rip is
         bug-free.
         "OK, so they asked me to do a dancey remix of Rob Hubbards classic C64
         theme and they wanted scratch sounds in it. I went over the top. I'm
         sorry Rob." (BL)

/Leitch_Barry/Just_Call_Me_Ben.sid
COMMENT: "Just trying to sound like Ben Daglish." (BL)

/Leitch_Barry/Live_To_Tell.sid
  TITLE: Live to Tell [from True Blue]
 ARTIST: Madonna & Patrick Leonard, Performed by Madonna
COMMENT: "Tone of the MILLIONS of demos we produced leading up to the ICUPS
         purchase, I was spewing out 3 or more tunes a day at this point, so
         what if it doesnt sound like the original, I DIDNT have a copy of the
         original to listen to, I didnt know what it sounds like,.. I dont even
         like Madonna... Can u tell ?" (BL)

/Leitch_Barry/Living_OK.sid
  TITLE: That's Livin' Alright [from the TV series Auf Wiedersehen Pet]
 ARTIST: Joe Fagin

/Leitch_Barry/Marauder.sid
COMMENT: "Written while I was still living in Scotland, Robert Magowan wrote
         the game and Mark Kelly took all the credit, got the good job and
         moved to California... Cant blame him really :) I think this was the
         first time I'd done anything on the 64 that was vaguely acceptable."
         (BL)

/Leitch_Barry/Miami_Vice.sid
  TITLE: Miami Vice Theme [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: Jan Hammer

/Leitch_Barry/Mindsmear.sid
COMMENT: "Written for the ZZap 64 Mindsmear April Fools Day competition. I got
         2nd prize... Years later I met up with the Zzap reviewers who had made
         the decision as to who won.. The reason the other guy won was because
         he'd written like 20 tunes and sent them all in so they let him win
         for doing so much work, but they all agreed mine was better ! :)
         HAHAHAH I've waited 11 years to tell that story!" (BL) ("the other
         guy" = Anthony Lees)

         Postman Pat was another, and I'm damned if I can remember what the 3rd
         was... probably Emlyn Hughes Soccer on re-release." (BL)

/Leitch_Barry/Shrink_to_Fit.sid
  TITLE: What a Wonderful World
 ARTIST: Sam Cooke
COMMENT: It's called "Shrink to Fit" because it was featured in a famous Jeans
         advert, which is why there is the police siren at the beginning (the
         advert featured a police car at the beginning). (Info from Chris
         Abbott)

/Leitch_Barry/Silkworm.sid
  TITLE: Ingame [from the arcade game Silk Worm]
 ARTIST: <?>
COMMENT: Almost all copies of the game had a bug in the tape loader routine
         which would mean the music corrupts itself around the 1:20 mark. This
         version is now bug free.
         Not a cover of the arcade original, but definitely inspired by it.

/Leitch_Barry/Sophistry_war.sid
COMMENT: The tunes in this SID were meant to be for the game Sophistry,
         programmed by Mark Kelly of the team Aracnum Developments (whom Barry
         was also a member of at the time). According to Mark Kelly, the game
         was to be published by Hewson but due to licencing disagreements with
         Firebird (Sophistry being similar to Firebird's Zolyx) the game was
         cancelled.

/Leitch_Barry/Tenko.sid
  TITLE: Tenko Theme [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: James Harpham
COMMENT: "No it wasnae me, someone else must have written my name... LOL
         OK, OK it was me..  I did the music in about 20 minutes and my mate
         drew the picture in even less time, TADA, instant Commodore 64 demo...
         Fame fortune and a life of torture ahead of u for churning out shite
         like that.. The out of tune pings were our way of saying "Yeah this is
         shit, but we did it"... which is more than can be said for others..."
         (BL)

/Leitch_Barry/Xenophobe.sid
COMMENT: "I got the one of the highest ratings I've ever got for this.. Zzap
         64 gave me 96% for it.. one of the others was Impossamole on the NEC.
         I have a copy of that somewhere but havent had the chance to try out
         the emulator." (BL)
(#1)
COMMENT: "I used a lot of filters in the loading tune [...]" (BL)
(#2)
COMMENT: The digitized voice is actually Barry Leitch himself. The original
         Xenophobe theme, was written and 4 Amiga networked using 16 channels
         and was originally included as a tape in the package of the game. The
         original music features the speech of Neil Young, who is now the head
         of Origin, which could not be used in the C64 version of the game for
         legal reasons.

/Leitch_Barry/Xenophobe_PSID.sid
COMMENT: "I got the one of the highest ratings I've ever got for this.. Zzap
         64 gave me 96% for it.. one of the others was Impossamole on the NEC.
         I have a copy of that somewhere but havent had the chance to try out
         the emulator." (BL)
(#1)
COMMENT: "I used a lot of filters in the loading tune [...]" (BL)
(#2)
COMMENT: The digitized voice is actually Barry Leitch himself. The original
         Xenophobe theme, was written and 4 Amiga networked using 16 channels
         and was originally included as a tape in the package of the game. The
         original music features the speech of Neil Young, who is now the head
         of Origin, which could not be used in the C64 version of the game for
         legal reasons.
